title: What happens to a suspended california corp that never did nor will ever do any business? do i have to dissolve and pay?
question: i opened a corporation in california in 09, never did any business (no assets, no debts) it is now in suspended status. if i have no plans on reviving the corp or doing any business under that corp name again, do i have to dissolve it and pay all the fees or does a suspended corp eventually go away and stop accruing fees? will my credit be affected since it was my SSN that is on the documents? any help is appreciated.
question_tags: Small business taxes,Bankruptcy,Credit score,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Business,Tax law
answers: There is no requirement to formally dissolve the corporation, and it is the corporation as an entity whch owes the Franchise Tax.

Not that the Franchise Tax Board has been aggressive to date in its enforcement of the Revenue & Taxation Code, but you do have something that you should be looking for over your shoulder. Not filing tax returns for your corporation is illegal. In a vacuum, the tax liability belongs to the corporation and you can probably walk away. In the real world where the state is going broke and will eventually be looking for untapped sources of revenue, I wouldn't allow a client of mine to sit back and do nothing unless I had fully explained the risks of not taking action with the Secretary of State and the Franchise Tax Board. BTW - same issues for be IRS as the FTB!

The suspended corporation just stays a suspended corporation. You do not have to dissolve it. You do not have to pay the back minimum franchise taxes.

The obligation to pay the taxes belongs to the corporation, not you individually, so failure to pay does not affect your credit score.
